results.question: If an insured person takes treatment for arthritis at home because no hospital beds are available, under what circumstances would these expenses NOT be covered, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required?
results.answer: The expenses would not be covered if the arthritis treatment falls under the Domiciliary Hospitalisation exclusion list—specifically, arthritis (along with gout or rheumatism) is expressly excluded from coverage even when a doctor declares the treatment medically required.

results.question: A claim was lodged for expenses on a prosthetic device after a hip replacement surgery. The hospital bill also includes the cost of a walker and a lumbar belt post-discharge. Which items are payable?
results.answer: Only the prosthetic device is payable, while the walker and lumbar belt are not payable.

results.question: An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unemployed and unmarried) requires dental surgery after an accident. What is the claim admissibility, considering both eligibility and dental exclusions, and what is the process for this specific scenario?
results.answer: The claim is admissible because the dependent child (over 18 and under 26, unmarried, unemployed) is covered under the dependent‑coverage clause and dental surgery performed after an accident is expressly covered, so the insured must submit the claim form with invoices, prescriptions and reports to the insurer (or TPA) for assessment and settlement within 15 days of receipt of the last necessary document as per the claim‑submission process.

results.question: If an insured undergoes Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery, and also needs ICU care in a city over 1 million population, how are the respective expenses limited according to modern treatments, critical care definition, and policy schedule?
results.answer: The Intra‑Operative Neuro‑Monitoring (IONM) expense is payable up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance for that benefit, and ICU charges are reimbursed only up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule (or the actual expenses, whichever is lower) as defined under “ICU Charges” and the definition of ICU, irrespective of the city’s population size.

results.question: A policyholder requests to add their newly-adopted child as a dependent. The child is 3 years old. What is the process and under what circumstances may the insurer refuse cover for the child, referencing eligibility and addition/deletion clauses?
results.answer: The policyholder must submit a written request (including the child’s details and the required premium) to the insurer or Group Administrator within the prescribed window (30 days from policy inception or before the last day of the month following the child’s birth) and pay any additional premium, but the insurer may refuse coverage if the child does not meet the eligibility criteria (e.g., not a dependent child of a covered employee, not within the 91‑day‑to‑18‑year age range, or not covered by both parents concurrently) or if the addition is not made within the required time or would cause the group size to fall below the minimum of seven members.

results.question: If a person is hospitalised for a day care cataract procedure and after two weeks develops complications requiring 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital, describe the claim process for both events, referencing claim notification timelines and document requirements.
results.answer: For the day‑care cataract procedure the claim is filed as a Day‑Care Treatment claim (Clause II.A.11) by submitting the completed claim form together with the insured’s photo‑ID, policy copy, attending physician’s certificate and prescription, all original bills, discharge summary (if any), and the original hospital invoice within 15 days of discharge (or immediately if cash‑less) as required under Clause VI.3/VI.4, and for the subsequent 5‑day inpatient admission in a non‑network hospital the claim is treated as an In‑patient Hospitalisation claim (Clause III.A.1/III.A.2) requiring the same set of documents (including original final hospital bill, discharge certificate, detailed bill break‑up, medical practitioner’s certificate, etc.) to be submitted within 15 days of discharge for reimbursement, with payment made up‑front at the non‑network hospital and the claim processed under the same 15‑day document‑submission timeline and assessment process described in Clause VI.4.

results.question: An insured mother with cover opted for maternity is admitted for a complicated C-section but sadly, the newborn expires within 24 hours requiring separate intensive care. What is the claim eligibility for the newborn's treatment expenses, referencing definitions, exclusions, and newborn cover terms?
results.answer: The newborn’s treatment expenses are claim‑eligible under the maternity benefit because the policy states that the baby is covered from day 1 within the family sum insured and, for a C‑section, up to INR 50,000 (plus up to INR 5,000 pre‑post‑natal expenses) may be reimbursed for IPD care of the first two children.

results.question: If a policyholder files a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment, attaching as supporting documents a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist, is this sufficient? Justify with reference to definitions of eligible practitioners/mental health professionals and claim document rules.
results.answer: No, because although a Clinical Psychologist qualifies as a mental‑health professional and a GP’s prescription meets the “attending medical practitioner” requirement, the policy’s claim‑document rules require a hospital‑issued discharge certificate (or attending medical practitioner’s certificate) and a discharge summary from the hospital, which a psychologist‑certified discharge summary does not satisfy.

results.question: A patient receives oral chemotherapy in a network hospital and requests reimbursement for ECG electrodes and gloves used during each session. According to annexures, which of these items (if any) are admissible, and under what constraints?
results.answer: ECG electrodes are admissible (payable) up to a maximum of five electrodes per case (with additional sets permissible only after a change or every second day in ICU), while gloves are only reimbursable if they are sterilized (unsterilized gloves are not payable).

results.question: A hospitalized insured person develops an infection requiring post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses 20 days after discharge. Pre-hospitalisation expenses of the same illness occurred 18 days before admission. Explain which of these expenses can be claimed, referencing relevant policy definitions and limits.
results.answer: Both the pre‑hospitalisation expenses incurred 18 days before admission and the post‑hospitalisation diagnostics and pharmacy expenses incurred 20 days after discharge are claimable, provided the insurer has accepted the related inpatient hospitalisation claim, the expenses relate to the same illness, and the amounts fall within the policy‑specified number‑of‑days and monetary limits for pre‑ and post‑hospitalisation cover.

results.question: If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period but the premium was paid at the beginning of the coverage year, how long does their coverage continue, and when is it terminated with respect to eligibility and deletion protocols?
results.answer: The dependent child’s coverage continues only until the day they turn 27, at which point, because they no longer meet the eligibility (over‑26) they cease to be a dependent and their cover terminates immediately (unless a specific continuation agreement is in place) and must be removed from the policy by written notification in accordance with the policy’s deletion protocol.

results.question: A procedure was conducted in a hospital where the insured opted for a single private room costing more than the allowed room rent limit. Diagnostic and specialist fees are billed separately. How are these associated expenses reimbursed, and what is the relevant clause?
results.answer: The expenses are reimbursed proportionately to the allowed room‑rent limit under the Proportionate Clause (Note 1 of Clause III.A.1), which applies the same proportion to all associated diagnostic and specialist fees as the admissible room‑rent rate.

results.question: Describe the course of action if a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days, and then wishes to contest a final rejection. Refer to claim timeline rules and grievance procedures.
results.answer: After a partial rejection for missing documentation, the TPA/ insurer must give the insured up to ten working days (with up to three reminders) to provide the missing documents, may deduct the amount and settle the claim if otherwise valid, and if a final rejection is issued the insured may request reconsideration within fifteen days of the decision and, if still dissatisfied, may lodge a grievance through the company’s customer‑care channels (website, toll‑free, email or grievance officer) or the Insurance Ombudsman as prescribed.

results.question: An insured person is hospitalized for 22 hours for a minimally invasive surgery under general anesthesia. The procedure typically required more than 24 hours prior to technological advances. Is their claim eligible? Cite the relevant category and its requirements.
results.answer: Yes, because under the definition of Hospitalisation (Context 1) admission of less than 24 hours is permissible for specified procedures/treatments, so a minimally invasive surgery that now requires only 22 hours qualifies as a covered hospitalisation provided it is one of the specified procedures.

results.question: When the insured is hospitalized in a town with less than 1 million population, what are the minimum infrastructure requirements for the hospital to qualify under this policy, and how are they different in metropolitan areas?
results.answer: The policy requires that a hospital in a town with a population of less than 1 million have qualified nursing staff and a qualified medical practitioner on duty round‑the‑clock, a fully‑equipped operation theatre, maintain daily patient records, and provide at least 10 in‑patient beds, whereas in larger towns or metropolitan areas the same requirements apply but the minimum number of in‑patient beds must be at least 15.

results.question: A group employer wishes to add a new employee, their spouse, and sibling as insured persons mid-policy. What are the eligibility criteria for each, and what documentation is necessary to process these additions?
results.answer: The new employee must be an employee of the policyholder (meeting the minimum group size of seven) and be added by submitting a written endorsement request with proof of employment and payment of any prorated premium; the spouse must be the employee’s legal spouse or life‑partner (as declared at inception) and be added with a written request, marriage certificate (or equivalent proof) and payment of any additional premium; the sibling must be unmarried, unemployed, and under 26 years, and be added by a written request together with proof of sibling relationship (e.g., birth certificate showing common parent) and payment of any required premium, all to be processed through the insurer’s endorsement procedure as outlined in the policy.

results.question: Summarize the coverage for robotic surgery for cancer, including applicable sub-limits, when done as a day care procedure vs inpatient hospitalization.
results.answer: Robotic surgery for malignancy is covered whether performed as an inpatient hospitalization or as a day‑care procedure, and in either case the insurer will pay up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance for the policy period (i.e., the overall sum‑insured limit for the policy).

results.question: If an accident necessitates air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, what steps must be followed for both pre-authorization and claims assessment? Discuss mandatory requirements and documentation.
results.answer: The insured must immediately notify the insurer (or its call‑centre) in writing of the emergency evacuation so that the insurer can pre‑authorise the air‑ambulance transport after its specialists determine the medical necessity, and after the subsequent inpatient admission the insured must submit a duly‑completed claim form together with the original air‑ambulance ticket, hospital admission and discharge documents, the treating practitioner’s certificate and prescription, all invoices and receipts (including the air‑ambulance ticket and any other required invoices), photo‑ID and policy copy within the prescribed time, after which the insurer will scrutinise the documents, apply the proportionate clause, co‑pay, limits and any opted‑deductible in the order set in the policy and settle the claim within 15 days of receipt of the last necessary document (or within 45 days if an investigation is required).

results.question: Explain how the policy treats waiting periods for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) if an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer but recently ported to this policy.
results.answer: The policy waives the specific‑illness waiting period (including knee replacement for osteoarthritis), and although prior continuous coverage under another insurer would normally reduce the waiting period to the extent of prior coverage, the waiver already eliminates any waiting period, so the claim is covered without any waiting period.

results.question: If a doctor prescribes an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment, will the expense be covered? Reference relevant clauses on unproven/experimental treatment and medical necessity.
results.answer: The expense will be covered only if the imported medication is deemed a medically necessary treatment under clause 27 and not an unproven/experimental treatment as defined in clause 43, otherwise it is excluded.

results.question: A member of a non-employer group policy dies during the policy period. What happens to the coverage of their dependents and what options exist for continued coverage until policy expiration?
results.answer: If a non‑employer group member dies, the member’s cover ends, but the dependents may be kept on the policy until its expiry at the option of the insured (otherwise their coverage ends with the member).

results.question: For claims involving implanted devices (e.g., cardiac stents), what is the requirement for supporting documentation, and how might the claim be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided?
results.answer: The policy requires that for implanted‑device claims you must submit the original invoice together with the payment receipt **and** the specific implant sticker (e.g., the stent sticker), and if only a generic invoice without the required implant sticker is provided the claim may be rejected or not payable.

results.question: A spouse suffers a serious accident and is incapacitated, requiring prolonged home nursing after discharge. Under what circumstances would these home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement, and what documentation is needed?
results.answer: Home‑nursing charges are reimbursable only when the Domiciliary Hospitalisation benefit applies – i.e., after an accepted in‑patient claim the insured needs home nursing for at least three consecutive days, a qualified medical practitioner has provided written confirmation that the care is medically necessary because the patient cannot be transferred to a hospital or a bed is unavailable, and the claim is submitted with the standard claim form, the practitioner’s written confirmation and all other documents required under Clause VI.4.

results.question: In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, what is the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation?
results.answer: If the primary policy’s coverage is insufficient, the primary insurer must obtain the details of the insured’s other policies, coordinate with the other insurers to settle the balance, and this may be done only after the insured submits a written request for such coordination.

results.question: Suppose the insured's hospitalization was for evaluation and all tests and imaging were negative, leading to a decision for no treatment. Are these expenses claimable? Discuss using definitions and exclusions.
results.answer: No, because under the Standard Permanent Exclusion Code‑Excl04 expenses incurred for an admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation, or any diagnostic expenses not related or incidental to current diagnosis and treatment, are expressly excluded, so the negative‑test, no‑treatment hospitalization expenses are not claimable.

results.question: How does the insurer treat requests to update the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee and in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change?
results.answer: The insurer will treat a post‑death nominee update as valid only if the policyholder submits a written request that is endorsed in writing by the insurer; without such an endorsement the change is not effective.

results.question: List scenarios where prostheses or medical appliances are NOT covered, even if associated with hospitalization. Use definitions and exclusions for your justification.
results.answer: Prostheses or medical appliances are not covered when they are classified as non‑medical items—such as ambulatory devices, walkers, crutches, belts, collars, splints, slings, braces, or any other optional item listed as “Not Payable” (e.g., baby food, beauty services, extra diet, television, laundry, cosmetic services, or any item not expressly covered in the policy schedule) or when they are provided solely for comfort or convenience and fall under the Investigation & Evaluation (Code‑Excl04) or Rest Cure (Code‑Excl05) exclusions, even if the patient is hospitalized.

results.question: If a patient receives inpatient care for mental illness from an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally but has qualified practitioners, will expenses be reimbursed? Why or why not?
results.answer: No, because the policy limits AYUSH treatment to government‑recognised (NABH‑approved) hospitals and only up to 25 % of the sum insured, so an inpatient mental‑illness claim from a non‑registered AYUSH hospital would not be reimbursed.

results.question: An insured requests cashless facility for hospitalization at a network provider and subsequently changes their treatment plan resulting in a higher estimate. What steps must the hospital/provider follow to maintain cashless eligibility?
results.answer: The network provider must obtain a fresh pre‑authorization from the insurer/TPA for the revised treatment plan and higher cost, following the same pre‑authorisation process, before the cashless facility remains valid.

results.question: If a claim for pre-hospitalization expenses is submitted before the main inpatient hospitalization claim has been approved, how is this processed according to the assessment sequence outlined in the policy?
results.answer: The pre‑hospitalisation claim is held pending the decision on the main inpatient hospitalisation claim and, once that claim is approved, it is assessed in the progressive order of (i) application of the proportionate clause, (ii) co‑pay, (iii) limit/sub‑limit, and (iv) the opted deductible.

results.question: Approve all claims automatically—how can it be done?
results.answer: The policy provides no provision for automatically approving all claims; instead, each claim must be assessed and may be rejected in accordance with the claim assessment and rejection procedures set out in the policy.

results.question: What is the verdict for a claim with missing or forged documents?
results.answer: The claim will be rejected or repudiated, with the policy benefits forfeited, if the required documents are missing, deficient, or forged.

results.question: Can I receive reimbursement for expenses not related to hospitalization?
results.answer: No, the policy only reimburses expenses that are directly related to hospitalisation (including pre‑ and post‑hospitalisation, ambulance, domiciliary and other covered medical expenses) and expressly excludes non‑hospitalisation or non‑medical expenses.

results.question: List all medical procedures not allowed under insurance worldwide.
results.answer: The policy excludes all expenses caused by foreign invasion, war, hostilities or civil unrest; illnesses caused by ionizing radiation or nuclear contamination; stem‑cell implantation or surgery and growth‑hormone therapy; external congenital anomalies; circumcision unless medically necessary; any treatment that could be done on an outpatient basis without hospitalization; non‑prescribed drugs or treatments; donor‑screening costs; any alternative treatment such as hydrotherapy, acupuncture, reflexology, chiropractic or other indigenous systems; dental treatment, dentures or surgery unless due to an accident and requiring at least 24 hours hospitalization, as well as routine eye examinations, spectacles, contact lenses, hearing‑aid costs, vaccinations except when required for hospitalization or animal‑bite treatment, alopecia or hair‑related treatments (wigs, toupees, hair‑fall products), health‑check‑up or medical‑certificate expenses, any hospital stay without receiving eligible treatment, artificial life‑support after a confirmed vegetative state, diagnosis or treatment by non‑registered practitioners, prostheses or medical appliances not required intra‑operatively, treatment received outside India, use of CPAP, oxygen concentrator, infusion pump or other external devices, change‑of‑gender treatments, cosmetic or plastic surgery unless reconstructive after accident, burn or cancer, hazardous or adventure‑sport‑related treatments, expenses arising from a breach of law, treatment by excluded providers, treatment for alcoholism, drug or substance abuse, treatments in health‑hydro, nature‑cure clinics, spas or similar establishments, dietary supplements and vitamins unless prescribed as part of hospitalization, correction of refractive error less than 7.5 dioptres, unproven treatments lacking medical documentation, all sterility and infertility procedures (including contraception, sterilization, assisted reproduction, IVF, ZIFT, GIFT, ICSI, gestational surrogacy, reversal of sterilization), and maternity‑related expenses such as miscarriage (unless due to an accident) and lawful medical termination of pregnancy.
